column1: Narsinghpur district (also referred to Narsimhapur district) is a district of Madhya Pradesh state in central India. The city of Narsinghpur is administrative headquarters of the district.As of 2001 Narsinghpur is the most literate district of MP.

column2: 125.55 km². The district is part of the Jabalpur Division. It is bounded on the north by Sagar and Damoh districts
column3: on the east by Jabalpur District
column4: on the southeast by Seoni District
column5: on the south by Chhindwara District
column6: on the west by Hoshangabad District
column7: and on the northwest by Raisen District. The administrative seat is Narsinghpur.The district sits in the basin of the Narmada River. The Vindhya Range skirts the northern end of the district. The Satpura Range forms the district's southern boundary. It is located between 220 55’ and 230 15’ north latitude
column8: and 780  38’ and 790  38’ east longitudes. It has an average elevation of 359.8 m above mean sea level.

column1: At the beginning of the 19th century
column2: Narsinghpur District was in the domain of the Maratha Bhonsle Maharajas of Nagpur
column3: and was known as "Gadaria Kheda". Soon a Ĵat leader occupied the place and built a large temple of Lord Narsingh on it. This led the city to be named Narsinghpur. Later this district was ceded to the British Raj in 1818. Narsinghpur District was part of the Nerbudda (Narmada) Division of the Central Provinces and Berar
column4: which became the state of Madhya Bharat (later Madhya Pradesh) after India's independence in 1947.

column1: According to the 2011 census Narsinghpur District has a population of 1
column4: roughly equal to the nation of Cyprus or the US state of Rhode Island. This gives it a ranking of 418th in India (out of a total of 640). The district has a population density of 213 inhabitants per square kilometre (550/sq mi). Its population growth rate over the decade 2001-2011 was 14.04%. Narsimhapur has a sex ratio of 917 females for every 1000 males
column5: and a literacy rate of 76.79%.At the time of the 2011 Census of India
column6: 99.57% of the population in the district spoke Hindi as their first language.

The main rail line from Mumbai to Kolkata
column2: which follows the Narmada River valley
column3: runs through the district from west to east.
